chdLesions.hemodynamics: Right-to-left shunt via VSD with RV outflow obstruction
chdLesions.presentation: Tet spells (hypercyanotic episodes), squatting preference, boot-shaped heart on CXR
chdLesions.murmur: Harsh systolic ejection murmur at LUSB, decreases during tet spell
chdLesions.management: Knee-to-chest positioning for tet spells; propranolol for spells; surgical repair by 3-6 months
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), CHARGE, Down syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Aorta arises from RV, pulmonary artery from LV; incompatible with life without mixing
chdLesions.presentation: Severe cyanosis at day 1-3 of life, no improvement with O2, single loud S2, egg-on-string CXR
chdLesions.murmur: Often no murmur early; may have systolic ejection murmur
chdLesions.management: PGE1 to keep ductus arteriosus open; balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind procedure); definitive: arterial switch (Jatene)
chdLesions.associations: Maternal diabetes, pregestational diabetes more than gestational

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Underdevelopment of LV, mitral/aortic valve atresia; RV-dependent systemic circulation
chdLesions.presentation: Severe cyanosis and shock on day 1-2 of life; soft or silent S2; no femoral pulses
chdLesions.murmur: Variable; may have continuous PDA murmur
chdLesions.management: PGE1 emergently; staged surgical repair (Norwood, Glenn, Fontan) or cardiac transplantation
chdLesions.associations: Maternal phenylketonuria (PKU), Down syndrome, Noonan syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: All pulmonary veins drain to systemic venous system; mixing occurs at ASD/PFO
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis, may present with pulmonary edema (if obstructed TAPVR), generalized edema, failure to thrive
chdLesions.murmur: Wide fixed split S2; may have ejection systolic murmur
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair; if obstructed or unstable → PGE1 to keep PDA open and improve mixing
chdLesions.associations: Heterotaxy syndromes (situs inversus), asplenia/polysplenia

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Absent tricuspid valve; requires ASD/PFO and PDA for survival
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis (day 1-2 life), single loud S2, no murmur or quiet systolic murmur
chdLesions.murmur: Quiet or absent; no systolic murmur from tricuspid regurgitation
chdLesions.management: PGE1; staged surgical repair (Blalock-Taussig shunt → Glenn → Fontan)
chdLesions.associations: Down syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Single arterial trunk overrides VSD, supplies systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulation
chdLesions.presentation: Mild cyanosis, bounding pulses (truncal valve regurgitation), wide pulse pressure, heart failure
chdLesions.murmur: Loud systolic ejection murmur at LUSB; truncal regurgitation (diastolic murmur)
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair (separate pulmonary arteries from trunk); PGE1 if PDA closure threatens pulmonary flow
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), increased in infants of diabetic mothers

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left-to-right shunt; size determines hemodynamic significance
chdLesions.presentation: Varies: small = asymptomatic; large = failure to thrive, cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema
chdLesions.murmur: Holosystolic murmur at LLSB (small VSDs); large VSDs may have softer murmur due to small pressure gradient
chdLesions.management: Small VSDs: observation (many close spontaneously); large VSDs: diuretics + ACE inhibitors; surgical closure if refractory heart failure
chdLesions.associations: Down syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome, CHARGE, fetal alcohol syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left-to-right atrial shunt; increased pulmonary blood flow
chdLesions.presentation: Often asymptomatic in childhood; may have dyspnea on exertion, recurrent respiratory infections
chdLesions.murmur: Wide fixed split S2 (even with expiration); soft systolic ejection murmur at LUSB from increased RV output
chdLesions.management: Observation in childhood; percutaneous or surgical closure if indicated (shunt ratio >1.5:1 or symptomatic)
chdLesions.associations: Ostium secundum ASD (70%), ostium primum ASD (15%), sinus venosus ASD (15%), Holt-Oram syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left-to-right shunt from aorta to pulmonary artery; increased pulmonary blood flow
chdLesions.presentation: Premature infants: often asymptomatic; term infants: bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, hyperactive precordium
chdLesions.murmur: Continuous 'machine-like' murmur throughout systole and diastole, best at LUSB
chdLesions.management: Premature: indomethacin/ibuprofen or acetaminophen to close PDA; if fails → surgical ligation. In ductal-dependent lesions: PGE1 to keep open
chdLesions.associations: Prematurity, maternal rubella infection, maternal NSAIDs in third trimester

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Narrowing of aorta, typically just distal to left subclavian artery
chdLesions.presentation: Hypertension in upper extremities, weak/delayed lower extremity pulses, narrow pulse in legs, rib notching on CXR
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at left infraclavular region; continuous murmur from collateral circulation
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair or balloon angioplasty/stenting; screen for associated anomalies (bicuspid aortic valve, Turner syndrome)
chdLesions.associations: Turner syndrome (15-20%), bicuspid aortic valve, hypoplastic left heart, mitral valve abnormalities

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left ventricular outflow obstruction; pressure overload → LVH
chdLesions.presentation: Often asymptomatic; severe AS: angina, syncope, dyspnea, sudden cardiac death with exertion
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at RUSB with ejection click (unless valve completely calcified)
chdLesions.management: Serial monitoring with echo; beta-blockers for symptom relief; valve replacement when symptomatic or gradient >60 mmHg
chdLesions.associations: Bicuspid aortic valve (most common), rheumatic heart disease, supravalvular AS (Williams syndrome, hypercalcemia)

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Right ventricular outflow obstruction; pressure overload → RVH
chdLesions.presentation: Often asymptomatic; severe PS: dyspnea, syncope, RVH, prominent RV heave
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at LUSB with ejection click; murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo sign)
chdLesions.management: Mild PS (<30 mmHg): observation; moderate-severe PS: balloon valvuloplasty
chdLesions.associations: Noonan syndrome, Williams syndrome, congenital rubella, Klinefelter syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Tricuspid valve displaced downward into RV; tricuspid regurgitation, right atrial enlargement
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis (variable), dyspnea, arrhythmias (WPW syndrome in 5-10%), right heart failure
buzzwords: right axis deviation with tall P waves
chdLesions.murmur: S3 or S4 (atrial gallop), tricuspid regurgitation murmur (holosystolic at LLSB), may have opening snap
chdLesions.management: Symptomatic: diuretics, digoxin; severe cases: surgical repair or valve replacement; manage WPW if present
chdLesions.associations: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW), maternal lithium exposure, Down syndrome

chdLesions.lesion: Atrioventricular Canal Defect (AV Canal/Endocardial Cushion Defect)
chdLesions.hemodynamics: Ostium primum ASD, inlet VSD, cleft mitral/tricuspid valve; left-to-right shunting
chdLesions.presentation: Holosystolic murmur, wide fixed split S2, signs of left-to-right shunt, early heart failure
buzzwords: Down syndrome (50% of complete AV canal)
chdLesions.murmur: Holosystolic murmur (mitral regurgitation), widely split S2, left-sided S3
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair (usually within first year of life to prevent Eisenmenger syndrome)
chdLesions.associations: Down syndrome (50%), trisomy 18, trisomy 13, Marfan syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Both aorta and pulmonary artery arise from RV; mixing via ASD or VSD
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis, single loud S2, symptoms depend on associated defects (VSD, ASD)
chdLesions.murmur: Variable; depends on associated defects
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair (depends on anatomy; may include Rastelli procedure)
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome, Down syndrome, heterotaxy

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Uncorrected left-to-right shunt → pulmonary vascular disease → reversal to right-to-left shunt
chdLesions.presentation: Progressive cyanosis, dyspnea, syncope, right heart failure; irreversible without heart-lung transplant
chdLesions.murmur: Single loud S2, early diastolic PR murmur (pulmonary regurgitation), no holosystolic murmur if shunt reversed
chdLesions.management: Oxygen, diuretics, digoxin; avoid pregnancy; heart-lung transplantation only definitive treatment
chdLesions.associations: Uncorrected large VSD/ASD/PDA, longstanding left-to-right shunt

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Patent foramen ovale; usually hemodynamically insignificant
chdLesions.presentation: Asymptomatic; right-to-left shunting only with increased right atrial pressure (Valsalva)
chdLesions.murmur: Usually no murmur; if significant shunt, may have murmur from pulmonary flow
chdLesions.management: Usually no treatment; consider closure if paradoxical embolism, recurrent strokes, or migraine with aura
chdLesions.associations: Normal variant (25-30% of population), paradoxical embolism, cryptogenic stroke

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Complete discontinuity of aortic arch; RV-dependent systemic circulation via PDA
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis, shock, severe hypertension in upper extremities, absent lower body pulses, no improvement with O2
chdLesions.murmur: Variable; continuous murmur from PDA
chdLesions.management: PGE1 emergently to maintain PDA; surgical repair (usually within first week of life)
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), CHARGE, thymoma

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Narrowing above aortic valve due to elastin gene (ELN) deletion
chdLesions.presentation: Systolic ejection murmur, facial dysmorphism (elfin features), developmental delay, hypercalcemia
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at RUSB; may be louder in aorta than pulmonary artery
chdLesions.management: Avoid excess vitamin D and calcium; beta-blockers for hypertension; surgical repair if severe obstruction
chdLesions.associations: Williams syndrome (deletion 7q11.23), sporadic SVAS, heterozygous familial SVAS

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Absent pulmonary valve; right ventricle-dependent pulmonary circulation via PDA
chdLesions.presentation: Severe cyanosis from day 1 of life, single loud S2, RVH, no improvement with supplemental oxygen
chdLesions.murmur: Continuous PDA murmur; no valve sound from missing pulmonary valve
chdLesions.management: PGE1 to keep ductus arteriosus open; staged surgical repair (Blalock-Taussig shunt)
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome, Down syndrome, maternal diabetes

clues: CXR shows cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings
murmurQuiz.explanation: VSDs produce a holosystolic murmur loudest at the LLSB from LV to RV shunting. Large VSDs cause significant left-to-right shunting → increased pulmonary blood flow → cardiomegaly, FTT, and pulmonary overcirculation. The pansystolic thrill is classic for hemodynamically significant VSD.

clues: Continuous 'machine-like' murmur throughout systole and diastole
Bounding pulses with wide pulse pressure
murmurQuiz.explanation: The continuous 'machinery' murmur is pathognomonic for PDA. It occurs because there is shunting throughout the cardiac cycle from the aorta (higher pressure) to the pulmonary artery. Bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure (diastolic pressure drops due to diastolic runoff into PA) are classic signs.

clues: Soft systolic ejection murmur at LUSB
Increased pulmonary vascular markings on CXR
murmurQuiz.explanation: The FIXED split S2 (split even with expiration) is the hallmark of ASD. This occurs because increased RV output delays RV ejection. The soft SEM at LUSB is from increased RV flow (relative PS). ASDs often present later with dyspnea from chronic pulmonary overcirculation.

clues: 12-year-old boy with chest pain and syncope during sports
Systolic ejection murmur at left sternal border that INCREASES with Valsalva
murmurQuiz.explanation: The key finding is that the murmur INCREASES with Valsalva (decreased preload → smaller LV cavity → more obstruction) and DECREASES with squatting (increased preload → larger LV cavity → less obstruction). This is opposite to fixed AS. HOCM is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes.

clues: 6-month-old with new holosystolic murmur at apex
No rash noted, but had recent scarlet fever
CXR shows mild cardiomegaly, Carey-Coombs murmur heard
murmurQuiz.explanation: Rheumatic fever causes pancarditis. The holosystolic murmur at the apex (mitral area) is from mitral regurgitation. The Carey-Coombs murmur is a soft mid-diastolic murmur of the mitral valve in acute RF. History of Group A Strep infection (scarlet fever) is key.

clues: 8-year-old with new innocent murmur during febrile illness
No diastolic component, soft systolic ejection murmur
murmurQuiz.explanation: Still's murmur is a vibratory, SEM heard at LLSB in healthy children, often prominent during fever or increased cardiac output. It disappears with resolution of fever and has no associated cardiac pathology. Key: no symptoms, normal heart size, murmur resolves.

clues: Murmur only during sinus rhythm, disappears during tachycardia
murmurQuiz.explanation: WPW presents with narrow (or occasionally wide) complex SVT. MVP murmur disappears during rapid SVT when the valve prolapse is less pronounced. WPW has accessory pathway; classic presentation is palpitations from SVT, sometimes syncope.

clues: Newborn with severe cyanosis unresponsive to oxygen
murmurQuiz.explanation: d-TGA classically presents with severe cyanosis in the first days of life NOT improved by supplemental oxygen (because pulmonary venous blood cannot reach systemic circulation). Single loud S2 occurs from anterior aorta. Egg-on-string is from narrow mediastinum. Requires PGE1 and balloon septostomy.

clues: Toddler with weak lower extremity pulses
Rib notching on CXR, figure-3 sign
murmurQuiz.explanation: CoA presents with hypertension in upper extremities, weak/delayed femoral pulses, and systolic murmur from narrowing or collateral circulation. Rib notching occurs from erosion by dilated intercostal arteries (collateral circulation). Figure-3 sign is from the narrowed aorta with pre- and post-stenotic dilation.

clues: 8-year-old with history of Group A Strep throat 3 weeks ago
New systolic murmur over aortic area with early diastolic murmur
Janeway lesions on hands, splinter hemorrhages under nails
murmurQuiz.explanation: Endocarditis produces new murmurs from valve destruction (aortic regurgitation = early diastolic murmur) or vegetations. Janeway lesions (painless macules on palms/soles) and splinter hemorrhages are classic stigmata. Group A Strep can cause endocarditis. Positive blood cultures are diagnostic.

clues: Teenage girl with mid-to-late systolic click and murmur
Murmur and click occur EARLIER with Valsalva
ECG shows T wave inversion in leads II, III, aVF
murmurQuiz.explanation: MVP causes a mid-to-late systolic click from abrupt leaflet prolapse, followed by late SEM. With Valsalva (decreased LV volume), prolapse occurs earlier, so click/murmur move earlier in systole. Common in adolescent girls. May have benign or malignant form.

clues: 5-year-old girl with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, oral changes for 7 days
murmurQuiz.explanation: Kawasaki disease is a vasculitis of medium-sized arteries, particularly coronary arteries. Presents with >5 days of fever + 4/5 criteria: rash, conjunctivitis, oral changes, extremity changes, lymphadenopathy. Coronary artery aneurysms are the major complication. Most common cause of acquired heart disease in developed countries in children.

clues: Soft holosystolic murmur at apex from MR
murmurQuiz.explanation: Dilated cardiomyopathy causes ventricular dilation → MR from annular dilation → soft holosystolic murmur. S3 gallop is from rapid ventricular filling. Causes include myocarditis, metabolic disorders, maternal diabetes, medications. Presents with heart failure signs.

clues: Murmur heard best at RIGHT upper sternal border
murmurQuiz.explanation: PS has a SEM at LUSB (right-sided for pulmonary valve). Murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo sign) due to increased venous return to RV. Ejection click is present unless valve is severely stenotic. No cyanosis unless associated with ASD (right-to-left shunting).

clues: 3-year-old boy with cyanosis since age 1 month
Systolic ejection murmur at LUSB that decreases during tet spell
Child squats when short of breath, older sister has Down syndrome
murmurQuiz.explanation: ToF is the most common cyanotic CHD. Boot-shaped heart from RVH and AV-displaced aorta. Murmur decreases during tet spell (hypercyanotic episode with increased RV outflow obstruction → decreased flow across VSD). Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance → decreases right-to-left shunt. DiGeorge/Down syndrome associated.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Fever ≥5 days + 4 of 5 criteria: bilateral conjunctivitis (non-purulent), oral changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips), rash (polymorphous, non-vesicular), extremity changes (edema, erythema, desquamation), cervical lymphadenopathy (unilateral, 1.5+ cm)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echocardiography for coronary artery aneurysms/ectasia; elevated ESR/CRP, anemia, thrombocytosis (>450k), elevated transaminases
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: IVIG (2 g/kg) + high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses) started within 10 days of fever onset; then low-dose aspirin (3-5 mg/kg/day) for 6-8 weeks (or longer if coronary involvement)
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Coronary artery aneurysms (25% untreated), myocarditis, pericarditis, myocardial infarction, sudden cardiac death
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Most common cause of acquired heart disease in developed countries. INCOMPLETE Kawasaki disease: fever + <4 criteria but echo findings of coronary involvement. Recurrent Kawasaki disease occurs in <3%. Risk of IVIG resistance (10-20%) → need additional therapy

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Major Jones criteria (carditis, polyarthritis, chorea, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodules); minor criteria (fever, arthralgias, ESR/CRP elevated, prolonged PR interval on ECG); must have evidence of preceding Group A Strep infection
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Throat culture or rapid strep test (if recent), anti-Strep serology (ASO titer, anti-DNase B); ECG for PR prolongation; echo for valvulitis; elevated ESR/CRP
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Benzathine penicillin G 1.2 million units IM for acute infection (if positive strep); aspirin for acute carditis; corticosteroids if severe carditis; secondary prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin G monthly or daily penicillin V) to prevent recurrence
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Rheumatic mitral stenosis (most common), aortic regurgitation, pancarditis, permanent valve damage
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Jones criteria: need major + minor for initial ARF diagnosis; for recurrent ARF, need 2 major OR 1 major + 2 minor. Chorea (Sydenham chorea) can occur months after strep infection. Erythema marginatum is pathognomonic. Secondary prophylaxis continues at least 5 years (or until age 21, or longer if carditis)

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Viral prodrome → chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations, syncope; signs of heart failure (tachycardia, hepatomegaly, pulmonary edema)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Elevated troponin I/T, BNP; ECG shows diffuse ST elevation (unlike MI which is localized), PR depression, T wave changes; echo shows reduced EF; cardiac MRI can show myocardial inflammation/edema
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Supportive care; ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics for heart failure; IVIG for fulminant myocarditis; mechanical support if cardiogenic shock; avoid NSAIDs (may worsen inflammation)
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Fulminant myocarditis with cardiogenic shock, sudden cardiac death, dilated cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Most common cause of myocarditis in children is viral (enterovirus, adenovirus, EBV). Can mimic MI but coronary angiography is normal. Fulminant myocarditis has worse prognosis but may recover better than acute myocarditis. Consider cardiac transplantation if refractory.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Sharp pleuritic chest pain that improves with sitting forward; may have pericardial friction rub; signs of pericardial effusion (muffled heart sounds, pulsus paradoxus)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Friction rub on auscultation; ECG shows diffuse ST elevation + PR depression (stage 1), then diffuse T wave inversion (stage 2); echo for pericardial effusion; elevated inflammatory markers
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: NSAIDs (indomethacin, ibuprofen) + colchicine for viral pericarditis; corticosteroids if severe or recurrent; antibiotics if bacterial; pericardiocentesis if tamponade
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Pericardial effusion, tamponade, constrictive pericarditis (rarely), arrhythmias
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Viral pericarditis most common in children. Tuberculous pericarditis in endemic areas or immunocompromised. Bacterial pericarditis is medical emergency. Pulsus paradoxus >10 mmHg suggests tamponade.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Fever, new or changing murmur, splenomegaly; Duke criteria: major (positive blood cultures, new regurgitation on echo) + minor (fever, vascular phenomena, immunologic phenomena, microbiological evidence)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Blood cultures (3 sets before antibiotics); echo for vegetations, valve regurgitation, perivalvular abscesses; elevated ESR/CRP, anemia, hematuria
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: IV antibiotics for 4-6 weeks based on organism and sensitivities; surgical intervention if large vegetations (>10 mm), embolism, hemodynamic compromise, or prosthetic valve
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Septic emboli (brain, lungs, kidney), valve destruction, heart failure, conduction abnormalities, sepsis
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Risk factors: congenital heart disease (especially cyanotic), VSD, PDA, prosthetic valve. Streptococcus viridans most common in children. Staphylococcus aureus common in IV drug users. Janeway lesions and Osler nodes are classic (but rare). Roth spots on fundus. Splinter hemorrhages under nails.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Dyspnea, failure to thrive, fatigue, exercise intolerance; signs of heart failure (tachycardia, hepatomegaly, pulmonary edema, S3 gallop)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows dilated ventricles with reduced EF (<40%); ECG shows nonspecific changes; elevated troponin, BNP; cardiac MRI for assessment
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics, aldosterone antagonists; treat underlying cause if identified; consider device therapy (pacemaker, ICD, CRT) or transplantation if severe
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Heart failure, arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death, thromboembolic events, cardiogenic shock
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Causes in children: myocarditis (viral most common), muscular dystrophies (Duchenne), metabolic disorders, medications (chemotherapy, doxorubicin), infiltrative disease. Peripartum cardiomyopathy in adolescent females. Poor prognosis; many require transplantation.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Asymptomatic or dyspnea, syncope, chest pain, palpitations with exertion; systolic murmur that increases with Valsalva/decreases with squatting
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows LV hypertrophy (asymmetric in HCM), SAM (systolic anterior motion of mitral valve), LVOT obstruction; ECG shows LVH, deep Q waves, T wave inversion; cardiac MRI shows HCM pattern
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (disopyramide for additional negative inotrope); disqualification from competitive sports; ICD if high-risk for sudden death (family history of SCD, syncope, massive LVH)
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Sudden cardiac death (most common cause in young athletes), syncope, arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation, stroke, heart failure
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Autosomal dominant inheritance (mutation in sarcomeric proteins). Screening: family history, ECG, echo. Most common cause of SCD in young athletes. Murmur increases with Valsalva (opposite to fixed AS). Avoid diuretics (decrease LV volume → increase obstruction).

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, peripheral edema; diastolic dysfunction with normal to slightly reduced EF
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows normal LV size with restrictive pattern (biatrial enlargement); Doppler shows restrictive LV filling; cardiac MRI for characterization
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Diuretics for volume management; avoid beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors (worsen diastolic dysfunction); treat underlying cause if identifiable
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Heart failure, arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation, thromboembolic events, sudden cardiac death
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Causes: amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, malignancy, infiltrative disease. Rare in pediatrics but important to recognize. Poor prognosis; many require transplantation. Elevated BNP and restrictive pattern on echo differentiate from constrictive pericarditis.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Often asymptomatic, discovered on prenatal echo or incidentally; may have arrhythmias, obstructive symptoms if large
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows mass, often multiple, benign appearance; cardiac MRI for characterization; associated with tuberous sclerosis in 50-80% of cases
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Observation if asymptomatic; surgical resection if obstructive, arrhythmogenic, or hemodynamically significant
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: LVOT/RVOT obstruction, arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death (rare), regression over time
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Most common cardiac tumor in children. Rhabdomyoma associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC1/TSC2 mutations). Many regress spontaneously. Check for TSC manifestations: skin lesions, seizures, renal angiomyolipomas.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Sudden collapse during sports after blunt blow to chest (baseball, hockey, lacrosse); immediate loss of consciousness, ventricular fibrillation
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Clinical history of traumatic chest blow preceding sudden collapse; ECG shows VF; history of survival with successful resuscitation suggests commotio cordis
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Immediate CPR and defibrillation; supportive care; implantable cardioverter-defibrillator consideration if recurrent events
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Sudden cardiac death, survival with neurologic sequelae if delayed CPR
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Occurs with relatively low-force blow to chest during vulnerable window (ascending phase of T wave); mechanism is electrical instability, not structural injury. Rare but catastrophic. Prevention: chest protective gear in sports.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Maternal SLE or Sjogren syndrome; infant presents with congenital heart block (third-degree), bradycardia, or cardiomyopathy; may have neonatal rash
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Maternal anti-Ro/SSA and/or anti-La/SSB serology; fetal/neonatal echo shows AV block; ECG confirms complete heart block
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Maternal corticosteroids during pregnancy to prevent progression; neonatal pacemaker placement if symptomatic heart block; supportive care
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Complete heart block requiring pacemaker, myocarditis, heart failure, intrauterine fetal death if severe
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies cross placenta and damage AV node. Risk 1-2% in maternal anti-Ro/SSA positive pregnancies; if previous child affected, risk increases to 15-20%. Diagnosis often made prenatally on fetal echo.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Syncope with exertion, auditory stimuli (Jervell and Lange-Nielsen), or at rest; family history of syncope/sudden death; may be asymptomatic
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: ECG shows prolonged QTc (>460 ms in males, >470 ms in females); genetic testing identifies mutations; stress test and Holter monitoring for arrhythmias
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Beta-blockers (propranolol, atenolol) as first-line; genetic counseling; ICD placement if high-risk or recurrent syncope despite beta-blockers; avoid QT-prolonging drugs
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Syncope, sudden cardiac death (especially during adrenergic surges), torsades de pointes, risk with fever or ototoxic medications
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Romano-Ward syndrome (autosomal dominant) accounts for 90% of LQTS. Jervell and Lange-Nielsen (autosomal recessive) includes congenital deafness. Trigger depends on genotype: LQT1/2 during exertion/emotion, LQT3 at rest/sleep. Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (macrolides, antiemetics, antipsychotics).

ecgPatterns.pattern: Right Axis Deviation (RAD) with Right Ventricular Hypertrophy (RVH)
ecgPatterns.description: QRS axis >+120°, tall R waves in V1 (>0.5 mV), deep S in V6, right atrial enlargement (tall P waves)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Normal in neonates and young infants (RV dominant at birth due to pulmonary vascular resistance). Gradual leftward axis shift occurs with age. RAD pathologic if persists beyond 6 months.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Don't confuse physiologic RVH in newborns with pathologic RVH. Neonatal RAD with tall R in V1 is normal; RAD in toddler requires investigation.

ecgPatterns.pattern: Left Axis Deviation (LAD) with Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH)
ecgPatterns.description: QRS axis <-30°, tall R waves in aVL and V5-6, deep S in III and aVF, increased voltage (Sokolow-Lyon index)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: LAD unusual in children; suggests significant LV pressure or volume overload. May see LV strain pattern (T wave inversion in lateral leads).
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: LAD in a child warrants cardiac evaluation for hypertension or structural disease. Don't dismiss as normal variant.

ecgPatterns.description: Heart rate typically 220-300 bpm in infants, 150-220 bpm in older children; narrow QRS (<0.09 sec); P waves often buried in T wave or after QRS
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Most common tachyarrhythmia in infants. WPW associated with Ebstein anomaly. Adenosine IV is first-line treatment to terminate SVT.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Narrow complex tachycardia in a young infant = think WPW/SVT. Adenosine will break AV nodal-dependent SVT; if not effective, consider atrial tachycardia.

ecgPatterns.description: Short PR interval (<0.12 sec), delta wave (slurred upstroke of QRS), wide QRS during sinus rhythm
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Accessory pathway conducts impulse from atrium to ventricle, bypassing AV node. Risk of sudden cardiac death due to rapid conduction during atrial fibrillation. Restrict from sports.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: WPW found on routine ECG + history of palpitations = needs cardiac evaluation. Do NOT give AV nodal blockers (verapamil, digoxin) as monotherapy; use flecainide or amiodarone instead.

ecgPatterns.description: QTc >460 ms (males) or >470 ms (females); normal QTc <440 ms in children
associations: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (autosomal recessive with deafness)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Risk of syncope and torsades de pointes with exercise, emotion, or auditory startle. Beta-blockers first-line. Genetic testing identifies mutation.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Prolonged QT + syncope = LQTS until proven otherwise. Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (macrolides, antipsychotics, antiemetics). ICD for high-risk patients.

ecgPatterns.description: PR interval prolonged (>0.20 sec in older children, >0.15 sec in infants) but each P wave followed by QRS
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Benign in many cases, especially in athletes. No hemodynamic consequences. PR prolongation increases with age normally.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: First-degree block alone is usually benign. Look for clinical context (myocarditis, fever, recent URI) before worrying.

ecgPatterns.pattern: Heart Block - Second-Degree AV Block (Mobitz II)
ecgPatterns.description: Periodic dropped QRS; PR interval constant in conducted beats; His bundle involved
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: More serious than Mobitz I; risk of progression to third-degree block. May require pacemaker.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Mobitz II requires urgent evaluation. Differentiate from Mobitz I (gradual PR prolongation before dropped beat) by constant PR in conducted beats.

ecgPatterns.description: No relationship between P waves and QRS; P waves march through QRS independently; slow junctional or ventricular escape rhythm
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Congenital third-degree block often well-tolerated (escape rate usually 40-60 bpm); acquired third-degree block more symptomatic. Requires pacemaker.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Neonatal third-degree block + maternal SLE/Sjogren = maternal anti-Ro/SSA antibodies. Bradycardia in newborn with cyanosis = consider heart block.

ecgPatterns.description: RAD (axis +60 to +160°), tall R in V1, deep S in V6, dominant RV, small/inverted T in V1-V2 (normal)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: RV dominance is physiologic in neonates due to pulmonary vascular resistance from fetal life. Gradual shift to LV dominance by 6-12 months.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Don't misread normal neonatal RAD as pathology. Axis gradually shifts leftward with age. By 6 months, should see shift toward normal axis.

ecgPatterns.description: Sawtooth flutter waves (F waves) at rate ~300 bpm (atrial rate), ventricular rate varies (often 150 if 2:1 conduction)
associations: Structural heart disease (ASD, VSD, Tetralogy of Fallot after repair)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Less common than SVT in infants but important to recognize. Often seen post-operatively after cardiac surgery.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Atrial flutter is organized; treat with rate control or antiarrhythmics. If hemodynamically unstable → synchronized cardioversion.

ecgPatterns.description: Wide QRS tachycardia (>0.09 sec), AV dissociation (P waves marching through QRS), fusion beats, concordance
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Rare in structurally normal hearts in children. Always indicates serious pathology. Requires urgent evaluation and treatment (amiodarone, cardioversion).
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Wide complex tachycardia in a child = assume VT until proven otherwise. Hemodynamically unstable VT requires immediate synchronized cardioversion.

ecgPatterns.description: Peaked T waves (tented appearance), wide QRS (>0.12 sec), peaked P waves, PR prolongation, ST depression, eventual sine-wave pattern
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Peaked T waves are early sign; progression to sine wave indicates severe hyperkalemia with imminent cardiac arrest. Treat emergently with calcium gluconate.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Peaked T waves on ECG = check potassium stat. Do not wait for clinical symptoms; ECG changes precede symptomatic hyperkalemia.

pharmacology.mechanism: Maintains patency of ductus arteriosus by preventing constriction of ductal smooth muscle
pharmacology.indication: Ductal-dependent cyanotic CHD (d-TGA, Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary atresia, critical coarctation, pulmonary stenosis, tricuspid atresia), ductal-dependent systemic lesions (interrupted aortic arch, critical coarctation, hypoplastic left heart)
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Given IV; must have intubation supplies at bedside due to high risk of apnea. Dosing: 0.1 mcg/kg/min, titrate to desired effect. Maintain body temperature.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: If cyanotic newborn does NOT improve with 100% O2 → think ductal-dependent lesion → start PGE1. Egg-on-string + single loud S2 + cyanosis = d-TGA, needs PGE1 + balloon septostomy.

pharmacology.mechanism: Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis → promotes ductal closure
pharmacology.indication: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants; alternative to surgical ligation
sideEffects: Oliguria, acute kidney injury (renal vasodilation effect reversed)
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Dosing: 0.1 mg/kg IV every 12-24 hours for 3 doses. Contraindicated if: active sepsis, thrombocytopenia <50k, bleeding, necrotizing enterocolitis. Monitor urine output and renal function.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Most common pharmacologic closure agent for PDA in premature infants. Success rate ~70-80%. If fails, or contraindicated → surgical ligation. Ibuprofen alternative with similar efficacy, potentially fewer renal effects.

pharmacology.mechanism: Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis → promotes ductal closure (alternative to indomethacin)
pharmacology.indication: PDA closure in premature infants; similar efficacy to indomethacin with possibly fewer renal complications
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Dosing: 10 mg/kg initial, then 5 mg/kg at 24 and 48 hours. Preferred over indomethacin in some settings due to better renal safety profile.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Ibuprofen vs indomethacin: roughly equivalent efficacy; ibuprofen may have fewer renal side effects, making it preferred in some premature infants with borderline renal function.

pharmacology.mechanism: Positive inotrope (increases contractility) via Na+/K+-ATPase inhibition; also slows AV nodal conduction (negative chronotrope)
pharmacology.indication: Heart failure in infants/young children; SVT (slows AV nodal conduction); atrial fibrillation rate control
sideEffects: Digoxin toxicity: nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias (PVCs, bigeminy, AV block), visual disturbances
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Narrow therapeutic window; requires careful dosing and monitoring. Loading dose varies by age/weight. Infants have increased digoxin sensitivity (increased Na+/K+-ATPase). Monitor for toxicity.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Digoxin loading followed by maintenance dosing. Hypokalemia increases toxicity risk. Used less commonly now (replaced by ACE-I and beta-blockers in heart failure), but still important for SVT in infants. Digoxin toxicity with hypokalemia → dangerous.

pharmacology.mechanism: Inhibits Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter in thick ascending loop of Henle → promotes sodium and water excretion
pharmacology.indication: Heart failure, pulmonary edema, volume overload from left-to-right shunts (large VSD, PDA), pericardial effusion
sideEffects: Ototoxicity (especially with high doses or renal impairment)
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Dosing: IV 1 mg/kg per dose, or oral 1-2 mg/kg/day. Potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone) often used concurrently to prevent hypokalemia.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Cornerstone of heart failure management in children. Must monitor K+, Cr, uric acid. Potassium supplementation or K+-sparing diuretics often necessary. Ototoxicity risk if furosemide given with aminoglycosides.

pharmacology.mechanism: Block conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II → vasodilation, reduced aldosterone, reduced afterload
pharmacology.indication: Heart failure (systolic dysfunction), hypertension, post-MI, renal protection in diabetes
sideEffects: Acute kidney injury in renal artery stenosis
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Enalapril: IV or oral. Captopril: oral. Renal function and K+ must be monitored. Contraindicated in pregnancy (teratogenic).
pharmacology.shelfPearl: ACE-I are first-line for heart failure in children with reduced EF. Used in large VSDs, dilated cardiomyopathy. Hyperkalemia risk, especially with renal impairment or spironolactone use. Monitor K+ and Cr at baseline and after initiation.

pharmacology.drug: Beta-Blockers (Propranolol for Tet Spells, Atenolol for LQTS)
pharmacology.mechanism: Beta-1 blockade: decreased contractility, decreased heart rate, decreased BP. In Tet spells, prevents catecholamine-induced RV outflow obstruction
pharmacology.indication: Tetralogy of Fallot (tet spells), long QT syndrome, hypertension, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, heart failure
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Propranolol: 1-2 mg/kg/day divided TID-QID. Atenolol: more selective for beta-1, better for LQTS. Avoid abrupt discontinuation.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Propranolol is first-line treatment for Tet spells; works by reducing sympathetic drive and increasing SVR. Atenolol used for LQTS, especially LQT2 with exercise-triggered syncope. Monitor for bradycardia and hypotension.

pharmacology.mechanism: AV nodal blocker; rapid increase in AV nodal refractoriness → termination of SVT
pharmacology.indication: Narrow complex tachycardia/SVT (especially WPW-mediated, AVNRT), diagnostic for reentrant arrhythmias
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: IV push: 0.1 mg/kg (max 6 mg), rapid flush if ineffective → 0.2 mg/kg (max 12 mg). Peak effect in seconds. Short half-life (10 seconds).
pharmacology.shelfPearl: First-line acute treatment for narrow complex SVT in children. Works immediately. Brief asystole is expected and does not indicate toxicity. Ineffective for atrial tachycardia or atrial flutter.

pharmacology.mechanism: Class III antiarrhythmic; blocks multiple ion channels (K+, Na+, Ca2+, beta); prolongs action potential duration
pharmacology.indication: Recurrent SVT (adenosine-resistant), ventricular tachycardia, atrial flutter post-surgery, hemodynamically unstable arrhythmias
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: IV: 5 mg/kg bolus over 20-60 min, then infusion. Oral loading/maintenance dosing. Monitor TSH, LFTs, CXR. Long tissue half-life (weeks to months).
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Powerful antiarrhythmic with multiple organ side effects; reserved for serious arrhythmias. Baseline TSH, LFTs, CXR before starting. Interactions with many drugs.

pharmacology.mechanism: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor; increases cGMP → pulmonary vasodilation
pharmacology.indication: Pulmonary hypertension (idiopathic, chronic lung disease, CHD-related), Eisenmenger syndrome
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Dosing varies by indication and age. Oral suspension available. Monitor BP carefully.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Used for pulmonary hypertension in CHD. In Eisenmenger syndrome, improves exercise tolerance and quality of life. Must monitor for systemic hypotension.

pharmacology.mechanism: Phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor; positive inotrope + vasodilator (inodilator effect)
pharmacology.indication: Acute heart failure, cardiogenic shock, post-operative low cardiac output, rescue therapy for septic shock
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: IV infusion: 0.25-0.75 mcg/kg/min, titrate to effect. Used in ICU setting. Requires close hemodynamic monitoring.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Useful when inotropic support and vasodilation both needed (unlike dobutamine which is inotrope + vasoconstrictor at high doses). Post-operative low cardiac output from cardiac surgery → milrinone is classic use.

pharmacology.mechanism: Anti-inflammatory (at high doses), antiplatelet (at low doses)
pharmacology.indication: Kawasaki disease (acute phase): high-dose aspirin + IVIG; prevention of coronary thrombosis (low-dose aspirin)
sideEffects: Salicylism (tinnitus, altered mental status, metabolic acidosis) at high doses
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: High-dose aspirin for Kawasaki: 80-100 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses until fever resolves + inflammatory markers normalize, then low-dose 3-5 mg/kg/day for 6-8 weeks (or longer if coronary involvement). Avoid in varicella/influenza (Reye syndrome risk).
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Kawasaki disease: IVIG + high-dose aspirin within 10 days of fever onset reduces coronary complications from ~25% to <5%. Low-dose aspirin continued if coronary artery involvement on echo.

pharmacology.mechanism: Immunomodulatory; may reduce coronary artery inflammation and thrombosis
pharmacology.indication: Kawasaki disease (acute phase), autoimmune myocarditis, neonatal lupus, various autoimmune conditions
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Kawasaki disease: 2 g/kg as single infusion within 10 days of fever onset. Reduces coronary complications significantly.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Kawasaki disease: IVIG is essential; combination with high-dose aspirin is standard. IV IVIG resistance (10-20% of cases) may require additional therapy (corticosteroids, second IVIG dose, or infliximab).

pharmacology.mechanism: Aldosterone antagonist; promotes sodium excretion while sparing potassium
pharmacology.indication: Heart failure (systolic dysfunction), hypertension, combination with loop diuretics to prevent hypokalemia
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Dosing: 1-3 mg/kg/day divided BID-TID. Must monitor K+ and Cr. Contraindicated if K+ >5.5 mEq/L or CrCl <30.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Often used with loop diuretics to prevent hypokalemia. Beneficial in systolic heart failure (improves mortality in adults; extrapolated to children). Close K+ monitoring essential.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 3-day-old infant presents with progressive cyanosis. On exam, there is a single loud S2. CXR shows an 'egg-on-a-string' appearance. The infant does not improve with supplemental oxygen.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the most appropriate initial management?
shelfScenarios.explanation: This presentation is classic for d-Transposition of the Great Arteries (d-TGA). The 'egg-on-a-string' CXR appearance is from the narrow mediastinum with anterior aorta. A single loud S2 occurs because the aorta is anterior and leaflets close forcefully. Severe cyanosis unresponsive to oxygen indicates ductal-dependent physiology. PGE1 maintains the ductus arteriosus for mixing at the ductal level. Definitive treatment is the arterial switch (Jatene) operation, but PGE1 is the emergent first step.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 4-week-old premature infant (28 weeks GA) develops respiratory distress with oxygen requirements increasing over days. Echo shows a moderate-sized PDA with left-to-right shunting and LV dilation. Urine output remains normal at 2 mL/kg/hr.
shelfScenarios.question: Which medication should be used first to attempt closure of this PDA?
shelfScenarios.explanation: Indomethacin (or ibuprofen) is first-line pharmacologic therapy for PDA in premature infants. Success rate is 70-80%. Key contraindications to indomethacin include active sepsis, thrombocytopenia <50k, active bleeding, and necrotizing enterocolitis; this patient has none of these. Normal urine output suggests acceptable renal function for safe indomethacin use. If indomethacin fails or is contraindicated, surgical ligation is the alternative. Maintaining PGE1 would worsen the PDA.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 5-year-old girl presents with 6 days of fever, bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, polymorphous rash, and hand edema. Labs show WBC 18k, CRP 95 mg/L, platelets 580k. Echo reveals dilated coronary arteries (4.5 mm, Z-score +2.5). No evidence of congestive heart failure.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the immediate next step in management?
shelfScenarios.answer: IVIG 2 g/kg IV + high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day)
shelfScenarios.explanation: This is classic Kawasaki disease with coronary involvement on echo. Diagnosis is made by fever ≥5 days + 4 of 5 criteria (conjunctivitis, oral changes, rash, extremity changes, lymphadenopathy). Coronary artery ectasia/aneurysms are seen in ~25% of untreated cases. Treatment with IVIG + high-dose aspirin within 10 days of fever onset reduces coronary complications to <5%. The combination is synergistic. Aspirin continues at low-dose (3-5 mg/kg/day) for 6-8 weeks or longer if coronary involvement. Methylprednisolone may be added if IVIG-resistant.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 7-year-old boy is brought to clinic after his mother noticed he would squat down during soccer practice when getting tired. On exam, there is a harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. CXR shows a boot-shaped heart. Oxygen saturation is 93% at rest, drops to 88% with exertion.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the most likely diagnosis, and what medication should be prescribed for acute hypercyanotic episodes?
shelfScenarios.answer: Tetralogy of Fallot (ToF); Propranolol for tet spells
shelfScenarios.explanation: Tetralogy of Fallot is the classic presentation: cyanosis with exertion, squatting position (increases systemic vascular resistance → decreases right-to-left shunt), boot-shaped heart on CXR, and harsh systolic ejection murmur at LUSB from VSD. For acute tet spells (hypercyanotic episodes), knee-to-chest positioning increases SVR, decreasing shunt. Propranolol is the preventive medication, reducing catecholamine sensitivity and RV contractility. Dosing: 1-2 mg/kg/day divided TID-QID. During acute spell: oxygen, morphine (reduces anxiety/RV contractility), and knee-to-chest positioning are immediate interventions.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 16-year-old girl presents with syncope during a school dance (loud music). On exam, she appears well. ECG shows QTc 520 ms (normal <460 ms). Family history reveals her maternal grandmother died suddenly at age 40. Genetic testing confirms KCNQ1 mutation (LQT1).
shelfScenarios.question: What medication and activities restriction are most appropriate?
shelfScenarios.answer: Atenolol and restriction from contact/competitive sports
shelfScenarios.explanation: This patient has Romano-Ward syndrome (autosomal dominant LQTS) with LQT1 genotype. LQT1 is exercise-triggered; she had syncope during exercise (dancing). Atenolol is the beta-blocker of choice for LQTS, especially LQT1, reducing catecholamine-mediated QT prolongation. ICD should be considered given family history of sudden death. All patients with LQTS should be restricted from competitive/contact sports. Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (macrolides, antipsychotics, antiemetics). Avoid cold showers (can trigger in some genotypes). Genetic counseling is essential.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 6-month-old presents with failure to thrive and recurrent respiratory infections. On exam, there is a holosystolic murmur at the LLSB, a palpable systolic thrill, and hepatomegaly. CXR shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Echo confirms a large mid-muscular VSD with Qp:Qs = 2.5:1.
shelfScenarios.explanation: A large VSD with left-to-right shunt causes significant pulmonary overcirculation (Qp:Qs >1.5:1) leading to heart failure, FTT, and recurrent respiratory infections (pulmonary edema). The holosystolic murmur and palpable thrill are classic. Management includes diuretics (furosemide) + ACE inhibitor (enalapril) to reduce afterload and improve cardiac output. If medical management fails or there are signs of deterioration, surgical closure is indicated. Many small VSDs close spontaneously; large symptomatic VSDs require intervention.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the appropriate initial medical management?

shelfScenarios.stem: A 4-year-old with Down syndrome presents with signs of heart failure: dyspnea, hepatomegaly, and a new holosystolic murmur at the apex. Echo shows an ostium primum ASD with a cleft mitral valve, left-to-right shunting, and mitral regurgitation. Qp:Qs = 2.2:1.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the diagnosis and appropriate management timeline?
shelfScenarios.answer: Atrioventricular canal defect (AV canal); surgical repair should be performed within the first year of life
shelfScenarios.explanation: AV canal defect (endocardial cushion defect) is very common in Down syndrome, occurring in ~50% of cases with congenital heart disease. It includes an ostium primum ASD + inlet VSD + cleft mitral valve. Progressive heart failure occurs as pulmonary vascular resistance drops postnatally. Without intervention, the patient progresses to Eisenmenger syndrome (reversal of shunt, cyanosis, irreversible pulmonary vascular disease). Surgical repair within the first year of life (ideally 3-6 months) is indicated to prevent this. Medical management (diuretics, ACE inhibitors) is bridging therapy only.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 2-week-old presents with fever (101.5°F), feeding difficulty, and a new systolic murmur at the LUSB (previously normal exam). Echocardiography shows 5 mm vegetations on the aortic valve. Blood cultures are pending.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the most appropriate management?
shelfScenarios.answer: Empiric IV antibiotics (ampicillin + gentamicin + cefotaxime for coverage of Group B Strep, Gram-negative organisms, and Listeria)
shelfScenarios.explanation: Neonatal endocarditis is a medical emergency. Early-onset endocarditis (first 2 weeks) is typically from maternal flora (Group B Strep, Gram-negatives, Listeria). Empiric antibiotics must be started immediately after blood cultures without waiting for results. Ampicillin covers Group B Strep and Listeria; gentamicin and cefotaxime provide Gram-negative coverage. Once culture/sensitivities return, antibiotics are tailored. Neonatal endocarditis has high mortality and requires aggressive treatment. Consider risk factors: prematurity, prolonged rupture of membranes, maternal fever.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 14-year-old boy with no prior cardiac history suddenly collapses during baseball practice after being struck in the chest by a pitched ball. EMS arrives to find him pulseless with VF on monitor. After 3 minutes of CPR and defibrillation, he achieves return of spontaneous circulation.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the diagnosis, and what is the mechanism of this cardiac event?
shelfScenarios.answer: Commotio cordis (cardiac contusion with electrically induced VF)
shelfScenarios.explanation: Commotio cordis is sudden cardiac death from a blunt, non-penetrating blow to the chest during a critical window (ascending phase of the T wave). The mechanism is electrical instability/VF triggered during ventricular repolarization, not structural damage (hence normal post-event echo and cardiac markers). It occurs with relatively low-force trauma in young athletes in sports like baseball, hockey, and lacrosse. Outcome depends on prompt CPR and defibrillation; survival with intact neurologic function is possible with rapid intervention. Prevention includes protective chest gear.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 6-year-old presents with 2 months of progressive dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, and orthopnea. Physical exam shows tachycardia, a soft holosystolic murmur at the apex, and a prominent S3 gallop. CXR shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary edema. Echo shows dilated LV with EF 35%.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the presumed diagnosis and initial management?
shelfScenarios.answer: Dilated cardiomyopathy (likely from myocarditis); ACE inhibitor + beta-blocker + diuretic therapy
shelfScenarios.explanation: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) in children is most commonly from viral myocarditis (enterovirus, adenovirus, EBV). Presents with heart failure symptoms and reduced EF. Management includes ACE inhibitors (enalapril) for afterload reduction and remodeling prevention, beta-blockers (carvedilol, metoprolol) for prognostic benefit, and diuretics (furosemide) for volume management. Digoxin may be added if needed. Cardiac transplantation is considered if medical management fails. Prognosis varies widely; some children recover fully, others progress to transplantation requirement.

shelfScenarios.stem: A newborn screened with pulse oximetry shows SpO2 of 85% in the right arm. No murmur is heard. CXR shows a 'snowman' sign. The child does not improve with supplemental oxygen.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the diagnosis and immediate management?
shelfScenarios.answer: Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (TAPVR); PGE1 + urgent surgical repair
shelfScenarios.explanation: TAPVR is a rare cyanotic CHD where all pulmonary veins drain to systemic venous system (SVC, IVC, coronary sinus, or portal vein) instead of LA. Cyanosis is present because mixing occurs at the atrial level (ASD/PFO required for survival). The 'snowman' sign on CXR is from supracardiac TAPVR (vertical vein dilated, creating snowman appearance). Unobstructed TAPVR presents later; obstructed TAPVR (veins obstructed at entry point) presents acutely with severe cyanosis, pulmonary edema, and shock. This patient needs PGE1 to keep PDA open for additional shunting, and urgent surgical repair. Without treatment, survival is impossible.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 10-year-old boy with history of acute rheumatic fever (treated 5 years ago) presents with new progressive dyspnea on exertion and decreased exercise tolerance. On exam, there is a diastolic murmur at the apex with an opening snap. CXR shows mild cardiomegaly. Echo shows mitral stenosis with valve area 0.9 cm².
shelfScenarios.question: What is the appropriate management at this time?
shelfScenarios.answer: Activity restriction, diuretics if volume overload present, and monitoring; surgical intervention (balloon mitral valvulotomy or valve replacement) if symptoms worsen or valve area <0.5 cm²
shelfScenarios.explanation: Post-rheumatic mitral stenosis develops years after acute rheumatic fever. The diastolic murmur and opening snap are classic. Moderate mitral stenosis (valve area 1.0-1.5 cm²) is usually managed conservatively with activity restriction and diuretics as needed. Surgical intervention (percutaneous balloon mitral valvulotomy or valve replacement) is considered if severe stenosis (valve area <0.5 cm²) or progressive symptoms develop. Children with history of ARF require continuous penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrence.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 12-year-old girl presenting with syncope during a school sporting event. Exam shows a systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border that increases with Valsalva maneuver and decreases with squatting. ECG shows LVH. Family history is significant for sudden cardiac death in her uncle at age 30.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the diagnosis and most appropriate next step?
shelfScenarios.answer: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM); echocardiography + ICD consultation given syncope and family history of SCD
shelfScenarios.explanation: HOCM is suspected based on the murmur dynamics: increases with Valsalva (decreased LV volume → more SAM → more obstruction) and decreases with squatting (increased LV volume → less obstruction). This is opposite to fixed aortic stenosis. Syncope + family history of SCD are high-risk features. Echo confirms the diagnosis (LVH, SAM, LVOT obstruction). ICD is indicated given syncope history and family history of SCD. Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are used for symptom management. Disqualification from competitive sports is mandatory.

shelfScenarios.stem: A newborn is found to have a continuous 'machine-like' murmur with bounding pulses and a wide pulse pressure. The infant was born to a mother who had rubella infection in the first trimester. CXR shows increased pulmonary vascular markings.
shelfScenarios.question: What is the diagnosis?
shelfScenarios.explanation: The continuous 'machinery' murmur, bounding pulses (from diastolic runoff into low-resistance pulmonary bed), and wide pulse pressure (elevated systolic, decreased diastolic) are pathognomonic for PDA. Maternal rubella infection is a classic risk factor (congenital rubella syndrome can include PDA, pulmonary stenosis, cataracts, deafness). In full-term infants, indomethacin or ibuprofen is used to close the PDA. In premature infants on positive pressure ventilation, the PDA may be tolerated. If pharmacologic closure fails, surgical ligation is an option.

shelfScenarios.stem: A 5-year-old boy with cyanotic congenital heart disease (Tetralogy of Fallot s/p repair 2 years ago) is brought to the ER with hemoptysis. On exam, he is cyanotic (SpO2 80-85%), has tachypnea, and a loud P2. CXR shows dilated pulmonary arteries. Echocardiography demonstrates severe pulmonary hypertension with bidirectional shunting across the remaining ASD. Mixed venous O2 sat is 60%.
shelfScenarios.question: What life-threatening condition has likely developed, and what is contraindicated?
shelfScenarios.answer: Eisenmenger syndrome (reversal of left-to-right shunt to right-to-left due to pulmonary vascular disease); surgical repair of the defect is contraindicated
shelfScenarios.explanation: Eisenmenger syndrome develops from chronic left-to-right shunting causing pulmonary vascular disease. Once pulmonary vascular resistance equals or exceeds systemic resistance, the shunt reverses to right-to-left → cyanosis develops/worsens. This is irreversible and likely in uncorrected large shunts or inadequately repaired defects. Once Eisenmenger is established, surgical closure of the defect is contraindicated because the right-to-left shunt is necessary for survival (to decompress the RV). Medical management includes oxygen, diuretics, digoxin, prostacyclins (epoprostenol, sildenafil), heart-lung transplantation in severe cases. Hemoptysis is from pulmonary infarction. Pregnancy is contraindicated (high maternal mortality).

clinicalPearls.pearl: Cyanotic CHD '5 T's': Tetralogy of Fallot, Transposition, Truncus, TAPVR, Tricuspid atresia
Acyanotic CHD rule: L-R shunt → increased pulmonary blood flow → NO cyanosis (unless Eisenmenger develops)
Ductal-dependent cyanotic lesions: PGE1 keeps ductus open for mixing; d-TGA, ToF, pulmonary atresia, critical CoA, TA, HLHS
Eisenmenger physiology: chronic L-R shunt → pulmonary vascular disease → shunt reversal to R-L → irreversible, surgical repair contraindicated
Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever: 2 major OR 1 major + 2 minor (with evidence of preceding Group A Strep)
Innocent murmurs: Still's murmur (vibratory), pulmonary flow murmur, venous hum; no diastolic component, no organomegaly, resolves with fever
Fixed split S2 = ASD; wide but variable split S2 = right bundle branch block or PS; paradoxical split S2 = aortic stenosis or LBBB
Sports disqualification: HCM, LQTS, WPW, commotio cordis risk, marfan with aortic dilation, coronary anomalies
Neonatal PGE1: cyanotic baby not improving with O2 → ductal-dependent lesion → PGE1. Must have intubation supplies ready (apnea risk)
Tet spell (hypercyanotic crisis): knee-to-chest position, oxygen, morphine (calms child, reduces RV contractility), beta-blockers prevent
Kawasaki disease: fever ≥5 days + 4/5 criteria; IVIG + high-dose aspirin within 10 days reduces coronary complications from 25% to <5%
HOCM murmur: increases with Valsalva/standing (decreased preload), decreases with squatting (increased preload). Opposite of fixed AS
Fetal circulation: PDA + PFO + ductus venosus allow shunting away from lungs + liver (both high resistance in fetus)
Neonatal ECG: RAD + tall R V1 is NORMAL; gradual shift to LV dominance by 6-12 months
Coarctation of aorta: weak femoral pulses, HTN in upper extremities, rib notching from dilated intercostal arteries
Water-hammer pulse = PDA or aortic regurgitation (hyperdynamic); pulsus paradoxus (>10 mmHg drop) = tamponade
DiGeorge (22q11 deletion) cardiac associations: ToF, truncus, interrupted aortic arch, PDA; think of CATCH-22
Down syndrome cardiac: AV canal (50%), VSD, ASD, ToF; screen all Down syndrome infants with echo
Marfan syndrome: aortic root dilation + aortic regurgitation; avoid high-intensity isometric exercise; beta-blockers or ARBs
Endocarditis prophylaxis: NOT routinely given; only for high-risk lesions (cyanotic CHD, prosthetic valve, PDA, VSD, CoA post-repair)
ACE inhibitors contraindicated in pregnancy (teratogenic); use in children for heart failure + hypertension
Digoxin toxicity: hypokalemia increases risk; signs = nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias (PVCs, bigeminy, heart block)
Hypertension in children: defined as ≥95th percentile for age/height; investigate secondary causes first (renal, vascular, endocrine)
Syncope workup: detailed history (exertional vs emotional vs positional), ECG (look for LQTS, WPW, HOCM patterns), echo, event monitor if unclear
Boot-shaped heart = ToF; snowman sign = supracardiac TAPVR; egg-on-string = d-TGA; figure-3 sign = coarctation

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Shunts blood from pulmonary artery to aorta, bypassing lungs (which are fluid-filled and high resistance in fetus)
fetalCirculation.postnatalFate: Closes within 24-48 hours after birth (functional closure); becomes ligamentum arteriosum (anatomic closure by 2-3 weeks)
fetalCirculation.closureStimulus: Increased oxygen tension, decreased prostaglandins, decreased pulmonary vascular resistance
fetalCirculation.pathology: Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) if fails to close; left-to-right shunting
fetalCirculation.pharmacology: Indomethacin/ibuprofen inhibit prostaglandins → promote closure. PGE1 maintains patency in ductal-dependent lesions

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Allows right atrial blood to bypass lungs, shunting to left atrium (one-way valve; higher RA pressure in fetus)
fetalCirculation.postnatalFate: Functionally closes within hours (increased LA pressure > RA pressure); probe patent in 25% of population (normal)
fetalCirculation.closureStimulus: Increased systemic venous return to left atrium (from pulmonary circulation), increased LA pressure
fetalCirculation.pathology: Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) if persistent opening; usually hemodynamically insignificant but risk for paradoxical embolism
fetalCirculation.pharmacology: No pharmacologic closure; surgical closure if paradoxical embolism or migraine with aura

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Shunts umbilical venous blood (oxygenated) directly to IVC, bypassing liver (hepatic blood flow returns via hepatic veins)
fetalCirculation.postnatalFate: Closes within 1-7 days → becomes ligamentum venosum
fetalCirculation.closureStimulus: Loss of umbilical venous return, increased hepatic blood flow
fetalCirculation.pathology: Patent ductus venosus if persistent; minimal hemodynamic significance
fetalCirculation.pharmacology: No treatment required; no pharmacologic closure agents

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Carries oxygenated blood from placenta to fetus; shunts most blood through foramen ovale + ductus venosus
fetalCirculation.postnatalFate: Becomes ligamentum teres (round ligament of liver) after cord clamping
fetalCirculation.pathology: Patent umbilical vein if persists; rare, minimal hemodynamic significance

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Carry deoxygenated fetal blood to placenta; arise from iliac arteries
fetalCirculation.postnatalFate: Become medial umbilical ligaments (obliterated) within 3-5 days
fetalCirculation.pathology: Patent umbilical artery if persists; rare, minimal hemodynamic significance

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Organ of gas exchange, nutrient absorption, waste removal; acts as 'lungs' + 'kidneys' for fetus
fetalCirculation.pathology: Placental insufficiency → intrauterine growth restriction, fetal distress
fetalCirculation.pharmacology: Maternal medications cross placenta (important for teratogenic drug avoidance)

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Pulmonary arteries are patent but pulmonary vascular resistance is very high (fluid-filled lungs); most RV output goes through ductus arteriosus
fetalCirculation.postnatalFate: After birth, lungs expand, PVR drops dramatically, pulmonary circulation receives most RV output
fetalCirculation.closureStimulus: Lung expansion, increased oxygen, decreased prostaglandins
fetalCirculation.pathology: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of newborn (PPHN) if PVR remains elevated after birth
fetalCirculation.pharmacology: Oxygen, nitric oxide, sildenafil to lower PVR in PPHN

fetalCirculation.fetalFunction: Fetus has three major R-to-L shunts: (1) ductus venosus bypasses liver, (2) foramen ovale bypasses lungs at atrial level, (3) ductus arteriosus bypasses lungs at arterial level
fetalCirculation.postnatalFate: All three close functionally within hours to days; become ligaments over weeks to months
fetalCirculation.closureStimulus: Birth → increased oxygen, decreased prostaglandins, altered pressure gradients
fetalCirculation.pathology: Failure of closure of any structure → persistent shunting (PDA, PFO, patent ductus venosus)
fetalCirculation.pharmacology: NSAIDs (indomethacin, ibuprofen) promote closure of ductus arteriosus; PGE1 maintains patency

sportsCardiology.risk: Most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes (<35 years)
sportsCardiology.screening: Family history of HCM/SCD, physical exam (dynamic SEM with Valsalva, LVH on ECG), transthoracic echo
sportsCardiology.management: Disqualification from competitive/intense sports; ICD if high-risk features (syncope, family history SCD, massive LVH >30 mm, abnormal BP response to exercise)
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Murmur INCREASES with Valsalva/standing (decreased preload) and DECREASES with squatting (increased preload). This distinguishes from fixed AS.

sportsCardiology.risk: Syncope with exertion, particularly LQT1 (exercise-triggered) and LQT2 (auditory startle), causing sudden death during sports
sportsCardiology.screening: ECG with QTc measurement (>460 ms males, >470 ms females), family history, genetic testing
sportsCardiology.management: Disqualification from competitive sports; beta-blockers (atenolol preferred for LQTS); ICD for high-risk or recurrent syncope; genetic counseling
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Trigger depends on genotype: LQT1/2 during adrenergic surge (exertion, emotion); LQT3 at rest. Avoid QT-prolonging drugs.

sportsCardiology.risk: Risk of sudden cardiac death from rapid conduction during atrial fibrillation (accessory pathway bypasses AV node rate control)
sportsCardiology.screening: ECG with delta wave + short PR interval; history of palpitations; cardiac stress test, EP study if high-risk
sportsCardiology.management: Disqualification from competitive sports until after ablation; antiarrhythmic therapy (flecainide) if symptomatic SVT; radiofrequency catheter ablation
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Do NOT give AV nodal blockers (verapamil, digoxin, adenosine) as monotherapy; may accelerate conduction through accessory pathway.

sportsCardiology.risk: Sudden cardiac death from blunt, non-penetrating chest blow during vulnerable cardiac phase (ascending T wave); occurs with relatively low-force trauma
sportsCardiology.screening: Clinical history of traumatic chest blow preceding sudden collapse and VF; occurs in baseball, hockey, lacrosse
sportsCardiology.management: Immediate CPR and defibrillation; neurologic support; ICD if recurrent events; prevention with protective chest gear
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Mechanism is electrical instability (VF), NOT structural damage. Echo and cardiac biomarkers normal post-event. Prognosis depends on speed of CPR/defibrillation.

sportsCardiology.risk: Sudden death during sports from exercise-induced arrhythmias; RV infiltration by fatty/fibrous tissue
sportsCardiology.screening: Family history, ECG (epsilon waves, T wave inversion V1-V3), echo, cardiac MRI (RV dilation + wall motion abnormality)
sportsCardiology.management: Disqualification from competitive sports; antiarrhythmics (sotalol, amiodarone); ICD for high-risk patients
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Rare; more common in Mediterranean populations. ARVC + exercise = high risk for sudden death.

sportsCardiology.risk: Sudden cardiac death during exertion if coronary artery arises from opposite sinus; artery compressed between aorta and pulmonary artery
sportsCardiology.screening: Family history of SCD, CT/MRI angiography, exercise stress testing showing ischemia
sportsCardiology.management: Surgical repair (unroofing); disqualification until after surgery
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Often asymptomatic until sudden death during sports. Consider in young athlete with SCD.

sportsCardiology.risk: Aortic dissection/rupture with exercise if aortic root dilated (>5 cm or >5.0 cm/m² BSA in children)
sportsCardiology.screening: Family history, physical exam (tall stature, arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis, pectus deformity), ECG, echo with aortic root measurement
sportsCardiology.management: Beta-blockers or ARBs to slow aortic dilation; disqualification from competitive sports if aortic root ≥5 cm; surgical repair if indicated
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Avoid high-intensity isometric exercise (weight-lifting, wrestling) which causes acute BP spikes.

sportsCardiology.risk: Arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death if return to sports too early after viral myocarditis
sportsCardiology.screening: Clinical recovery from viral illness (fever, malaise resolved), normalization of cardiac biomarkers (troponin, BNP), normalized EF on echo
sportsCardiology.management: Rest period of 3-6 months minimum; gradual return to sports after clinical recovery + exercise stress test clearance; avoid intense exercise during acute phase
sportsCardiology.shelfPearl: Premature return to sports after myocarditis increases risk of fulminant myocarditis and sudden death. Err on side of caution.
